image.altText: Recruitment difficulty not cause of Qantas' staffing crisis, CEO says

items.synopsis: Local shares make gains, but Fortescue shares drop. Qantas CEO Alan Joyce fronts a parliamentary committee on cost of living. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.Â

title.children: Qantas boss faces Senate over soaring airfares and profits, ASX rises, Fortescue shares down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: They only had an hour set aside for the hearing, but the rare opportunity for questioning of Alan Joyce saw it extended for an additional half an hour. Mr Joyce said they couldn't go on for too much longer because they, ironically, had a plane to catch (which committee chair Senator Jane Hume quipped "I'm sure it'll be delayed" in response). Here's a quick recap of what we learned from that 90 minutes: Mr Joyce refused to share detail about Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's son being granted access to the Chairman's Lounge, or any other details about the lounge citing privacy reasons Jetstar CEO Steph Tully confirmed the budget airline is holding around $100 million worth of flight credits, on top of the $370 million worth of Qantas flight credits disclosed last week Mr Joyce did not disclose the value of flight credits held by international passengers, but said it was "less than $100 million" Neither Mr Joyce, Ms Tully or Mr McGuinness ruled out the possibility of the flight credit deadline being extended beyond December this year, but said a line in the sand needed to be drawn Qantas is aiming to have zero outstanding flight credits left by December 31 And with that, that brings the blog to close to another day. We will have a complete wrap up of the explosive hearing shortly, but until then, you can catch up on today's developments below, or download the ABC News app and subscribe to our range of news alerts for the latest news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: That's it for the grilling of Qantas boss Alan Joyce

children.content: They only had an hour set aside for the hearing, but the rare opportunity for questioning of Alan Joyce saw it extended for an additional half an hour.
Mr Joyce said they couldn't go on for too much longer because they, ironically, had a plane to catch (which committee chair Senator Jane Hume quipped "I'm sure it'll be delayed" in response).
Here's a quick recap of what we learned from that 90 minutes:
Mr Joyce refused to share detail about Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's son being granted access to the Chairman's Lounge, or any other details about the lounge citing privacy reasons
Jetstar CEO Steph Tully confirmed the budget airline is holding around $100 million worth of flight credits, on top of the $370 million worth of Qantas flight credits disclosed last week
Mr Joyce did not disclose the value of flight credits held by international passengers, but said it was "less than $100 million"
Neither Mr Joyce, Ms Tully or Mr McGuinness ruled out the possibility of the flight credit deadline being extended beyond December this year, but said a line in the sand needed to be drawn
Qantas is aiming to have zero outstanding flight credits left by December 31
And with that, that brings the blog to close to another day.
We will have a complete wrap up of the explosive hearing shortly, but until then, you can catch up on today's developments below, or

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A slight delay, apologies, but the Australian share market has finished trade for the day and the ASX 200 finished 0.6 per cent higher. It was a decent effort but not as stellar as some other markets around the region, with Tokyo's Nikkei climbing 1.7 per cent. Most sectors of the local market rose, led by consumer, health and energy. The major banks helped the broader market rise, with a 1.3 per cent gain for NAB shares. On the flipside, Fortescue shares were down 5.1 per cent, after it announced a drop in profit and the shock exit of its metals CEO. There was another CEO exit that sent shares tumbling â Sayona Mining shares hit a two-year low on news its boss was resigning. AI chipmaker Brainchip also saw shares slump as its half-year results disappointed investors.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX closes higher as Asian markets rally, Fortescue shares drag

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas says it's holding around $100 million in credits belonging to Jetstar customers. Previously, the airline said it was holding $370 million in credits for Australian customers. But under questioning from senators in Melbourne, it said that doesn't include Jetstar or international customers. Executive Steph Tully says around 50 per cent of the credit is held by people with less than $100 in credit remaining.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas holding $100 million in Jetstar customer credits

children.content: Qantas says it's holding around $100 million in credits belonging to Jetstar customers.

Previously, the airline said it was holding $370 million in credits for Australian customers. But under questioning from senators in Melbourne, it said that doesn't include Jetstar or international customers.
Executive Steph Tully says around 50 per cent of the credit is held by people with less than $100 in credit remaining.
